CONSTRUCTION OF COMMUNITY
CENTRE FOR MOULMEIN
(Commencement and completion dates)


    1. Mrs Devan Nair asked the Minister of Defence when construction of the proposed Community Centre for Moulmein will commence and the estimated date for its completion.

    The Minister of State of Defence (Mr Wee Toon Boon) (for the Minister of Defence): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Minister has promised the hon. Member the last time she raised the subject that we are making a special effort to build a community centre in her constituency. ENTRY OF WIVES OF SINGAPORE CITIZENS INTO REPUBLIC
(Relaxation of rule)


    2. Mrs Devan Nair asked the Minister of Defence if he will consider a relaxation of paragraph 4 of the Schedule to the Immigration (Prohibition of Entry) Order, 1966, to allow wives of Singapore Citizens to enter the Republic though they may have been living separately from their husbands for more than five years.

    Mr Wee Toon Boon (for the Minister of Defence): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Government does not consider that a relaxation is necessary. The legislation was introduced after careful consideration of the implications of allowing wives of Singapore Citizens entry without control. The rule has been enforced since December 1959. The Government does not advocate and has no intention of relaxing the control. I would urge the hon. Member first, to ask why Singapore citizens should go overseas to get married when there are so many healthy, well-educated and intelligent young women in Singapore? Are they not doing a disservice to the country? And if, after having married, they have remained separate from their wives for more than five years, something extraordinary must have taken place. Whatever it is, it does not call for sympathetic consideration from the Immigration authorities.

    Mr Ng Kah Ting (Punggol): Mr Speaker, Sir, I would like to ask the Minister of State of Defence whether he is aware that permission has been sought to permit those wives of Chinese immigrants who have been separated from their husbands who came to Singapore, say, in 1947, to enter Singapore and whether consideration would be given to them?

    Mr Wee Toon Boon: Mr Speaker, Sir, as I have pointed out just now, the policy is that if the husband and the wife have been separated for five years and the husband is living here, then no approval can be given for the entry of the wife into Singapore.

Column: 1193



    Mr Speaker: I think Mr Ng's question was that the separation was involuntary.

    Mr Wee Toon Boon: Mr Speaker, Sir, another point is that if they have decided to reside in Singapore, become Singapore citizens and have stayed in Singapore, they should have made the necessary arrangements for their family, or other members of their family, to be together with them. If they have not done so earlier and they want to do it now, I am afraid that it is a circumstance beyond our control and it is no fault of the Government.

    Mr P. Govindaswamy (Anson): With regard to the Minister of State's answer, suppose the wife has been separated for five years, then her husband, who is a Singapore citizen, can marry another girl in Singapore?

    Mr Wee Toon Boon: Mr Speaker, Sir, as you are aware, and probably the Member for Anson is also aware, we have passed the Women's Charter in Singapore and, therefore, marriages are governed by the Women's Charter.

    Mr Govindaswamy: One more question. According to the Women's Charter, they should be separated for seven years, and then they can claim for a divorce. I wonder whether the Minister of State agrees with the seven-year period of separation.

    The Minister for Culture and Social Affairs (Inche Othman Bin Wok): The amendment Bill has not been passed yet.

    Mr S. Rajoo (Farrer Park): Mr Speaker, Sir, according to the Women's Charter, we are told that a man can marry only one wife. When people residing in Singapore applied for Singapore citizenship and got it, whether they came from India or China, and when they applied for an entry permit for their wife, who may be in India or China, they declare in the application forms that they are already married and have a wife. Will the Minister inform me how such people can, in those circumstances, get a divorce, thereby allowing them to marry somebody else in Singapore?

Column: 1194



    Mr Wee Toon Boon: Mr Speaker, Sir, this is not within my portfolio. I do not know whether the Minister for Social Affairs can answer it.

    Mr Speaker: Mr Rajoo, I think we had better wait for the debate on the Women's Charter (Amendment) Bill.

    Mr Rajoo: Thank you.

TAMIL PROGRAMMES OVER
RADIO SINGAPURA
(Complaints about poor reception)


    3. Mr S. V. Lingam asked the Minister for Culture and Social Affairs if he is aware of complaints about the poor quality of reception on the wave-length over which Tamil programmes are now broadcast by Radio Singapura; and, whether he will take steps to have this wavelength altered.

    Inche Othman Bin Wok: Mr Speaker, Sir, I am aware of the complaints about the poor quality of the reception on the wavelength 1370 k/c over which Tamil programmes are now broadcast. For this reason, I have made provision last year for the purchase of a new transmitter of 20 kilowatts to take the place of the old one of only 10 kilowatts. This new transmitter was installed in January 1967 and the reception of the Tamil programme should have appreciably improved.

    With the proposed installation of F.M. (Frequency Modulation) Transmitters in May this year for all language streams, it is expected that reception in all languages would be clear. There is, however, nothing wrong with the present wavelength.

Column: 1194

FLOODS IN CAMBRIDGE ROAD, OWEN ROAD
AND NORFOLK ROAD


    4. Mr S. Rajoo asked the Minister for Law and National Development, in view of the recent floods in the Cambridge Road, Owen Road and Norfolk Road areas, (a) if he will consider taking immediate steps, as a temporary measure, to raise the embankment and widen the canal between Keng Lee Road and the Kandang Kerbau Police Station; and

Column: 1195

(b) whether he will consider requesting the Housing and Development Board to give priority in the allocation of the Board's flats to applicants from these areas who wish to move out.

    Mr E. W. Barker: Mr Speaker, Sir, the areas about which the Member is worried are extremely low-lying and densely built up and are less than two feet above the level of the highest tide. Therefore, heavy rainfall coinciding with a high tide will cause flooding in these areas.

    Raising the Rochore Canal embankments, as suggested by the hon. Member, would mean raising the highest level of the water in the canal above that of the level in the culverts and drains leading into the canal. Therefore, unless control flap gates at the discharge ends of culverts and drains are built, the water from the canal could flow into the surrounding areas. If these flap gates are built and closed during heavy rainfall, the rain water in these areas cannot flow into the canal. If there is a high tide coinciding with heavy rainfall and the flap gates are opened, the water in the canal will be pushed by the tide and flow back into these low-lying areas.

    Immediate widening of the canal as suggested by the hon. Member would not be feasible, due to the fact that the existing roads on either side of the canal have been built very close to the canal embankments. Any minor widening will not do much to alleviate flooding.

    However, the Bukit Timah Flood Alleviation Scheme is being implemented to alleviate not only the floods in the Bukit Timah area, but also in these areas about which the Member is worried. Work on this major Flood Alleviation Scheme is now in progress and is expected to be completed some time in 1969. Mr Speaker, that deals with the first part of the question. If I may go on to the second part.

    Some priority can be given by the Housing and Development Board to applicants who wish to move out of these areas. For those already occupying

Column: 1196

Housing Board flats, transfers can be arranged provided they are not, choosey as regards location. In the case of those who are not at the moment living in Housing Board flats, they should apply in the normal manner, and if they are eligible under the rules, they can be allocated Housing Board flats within a matter of days provided again they are not choosey as regards location.

    Mr Rajoo: A supplementary question, Sir. Can the Minister tell me a little more about the flood alleviation scheme in Bukit Timah? If I am allowed to ask a second supplementary question, can he also say where flats are available for those people who want to move out?

    Mr Barker: The Bukit Timah Flood Alleviation Scheme is being implemented in two stages - Phase 1 and Phase 2. The Government has approved the implementation of the Phase 1 Scheme at an estimated cost of $6,840,000. Approval of the Phase 1 Scheme involves the construction of an entirely new canal which will divert the storm water from Upper Bukit Timah and Sungei Namly catchments, starting at about the 6th milestone Bukit Timah Road to join up with Sungei Ulu Pandan. This Phase has already commenced and, as I have said, work will be completed or is expected to be completed by 1969.

    Phase 2 of the scheme on which a firm decision has not yet been taken would involve another diversion of flood waters and would mean cutting another canal starting at about the 4th milestone Bukit Timah Road to join up with Sungei Kallang. This deals with the Member's first supplementary question.

    As far as the second supplementary question is concerned, there are flats in Toa Payoh, flats in Redhill, flats in Upper Changi Road and a few flats in Bukit Ho Swee which are readily available. In Upper Changi Road there are about 400; Redhill about 250; Toa Payoh a few thousand; and Bukit Ho Swee about 100.

HOUSING AND DEVELOPMENT
BOARD FLATS
(Choice of locality)


    5. Mrs Devan Nair asked the Minister for Law and National Development if he will request the Housing and Development Board to permit a choice of locality when they offer flats to applicants who have been given notice to quit State land.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for National Development (Mr Ho Cheng Choon) (for the Minister for Law and National Development): Mr Speaker, Sir, it has already been the practice of the Housing and Development Board to offer to families who have been given notice to quit State land alternative choices of locality where flats are available. NATIONAL SERVICE
(AMENDMENT) BILL


    Order read for resumption of debate on Question [13th March, 1967], "That the Bill be now read a Second time."

    Question again proposed.

2.46 p.m.

    Mr Bernard Rodrigues (Telok Blangah): Mr Speaker, Sir, another point which I wanted to bring to the attention of this House yesterday when the House adjourned is that while the Ordinance provides for the security of jobs of persons placed in the national service reserve, no provision is made to the effect that no person placed in the national service reserve shall be prejudiced in his employment by reason only of the fact that he is placed in the national service reserve for the duration of such reserve services. I have in mind the possibility that the person placed on the national service reserve may be placed at a disadvantage in respect of promotion opportunities as a result of his military training. Because of such military training requirements, he may not be able to carry out over-time work in his company whenever

Column: 1198

requested to do so by his supervisors. Because of such a situation, the management may place him in a section of the firm which does not carry much over-time requirements and, thereby, offers much less hope for promotion. Even if he is not required to perform overtime duties, the management, at the same time, may be irritated to a certain extent by the fact that such employee is compelled to take time off from work and may, naturally, react to such irritation by not actively considering such employee for any vacancy in a higher post whenever any such vacancy arises. It would be a sort of half-hearted compensation, if I may say so, for such employee to be assured of his security of employment but, at the same time, to suffer a certain degree of prejudice in his career prospects as far as his firm is concerned. I do not know whether it is implied in the assurance of the Government to those who are required to be called up for national service - that this assurance of a job to all who are called up applies equally to those who already have a job in a private firm, so that any person, whose career may be prejudiced by his military duty, will be given an opportunity for a higher job which he would otherwise have obtained if it had not been for his national service.

    Mr Lim Guan Hoo (Bukit Merah)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, on the National Service (Amendment) Bill, I feel that our brave Colonel should not be afraid of my raising any question on this Bill, as it concerns the life and death of the nation, and it is introduced at a time when the Communist united front is struggling. On the other hand, Britain is trying to cut down her troops and manpower in Singapore. So the introduction of this Bill at this juncture is of special significance, because it symbolises the fact that the people of Singapore will be able to feel and appreciate the end of colonial rule and that we are really independent in the true sense of the word. If we were still under colonial rule, then our colonial masters would still shoulder their military responsibilities to protect their own interests in this region. Therefore, while they

Column: 1199

controlled the military power in this region, they would not be able to carry out the job properly. For example, if they wanted the people to take up national service, they would meet with great difficulties and troubles. That was why some 10 years ago in Singapore there was the May 13th incident. This took place in a very abnormal situation and under very strange circumstances. The facts of the riots that took place then were distorted and exploited by some quarters.

    From the colonial rulers, we have inherited a situation in which we do not have sufficient military power. We have inherited a very weak and feeble civil service. We have not been given a very brave, strong and rugged military establishment. This Bill, which is now introduced about a year or so after our independence, throws some more light on the independence of Singapore in that we are now in charge of the defence of our own country. If we were still under colonial rule, we would not be given the full attention and care that we deserve. In those days, our colonial masters would not be able to fully implement national service. At that time, a lot of students applied for postponement from military service, and they fought very hard to get it. They thought they could get some kind of postponement. But now, in introducing this Bill, we have already made concrete proposals for its implementation. Regulations have already been drawn up to grant facilities to those students who want to apply for postponement on valid grounds. This goes to show that an independent government is entirely different from a colonial government.

    I wish to go on to another point. We can see that a lot of people feel that Singapore is completely indefensible. There is nothing for which we can fight. We cannot hope to triumph in any battle at all in Singapore. Sometimes we can see in the newspapers reports about military pacts entered into between Malaysia and the United Kingdom. Singapore is regarded as a small island, like the Isle of Man, at the southern tip

Column: 1200

of the Malay Peninsula. It is only a very small piece of land. It has no military significance and value, and it is completely indefensible. This kind of argument seems to have underestimated the military value and strategic position of Singapore. It is not entirely correct. If it is said that our military power is not sufficient to carry out any aggression, of course, I will agree. In fact, it is not our aim to mobilise our people in order to raise an army and go north, south, east or west. We do not have such aggressive intentions at all. Our main aim is centred on defence, and defence only. As a matter of fact, a small island like Singapore has, historically, no intention of any aggression at all.

    Some 700 years ago there was aggression from Java, and recently Japan also invaded Singapore. We were occupied by Japan and became the victims of aggression. But there is no intention on our record to say that we have invaded any other place at all. So even if we have a strong army, we do not have any experience of invading others, or have any aggressive intentions. Singapore controls traffic in the Straits of Malacca in a region of some 600 miles. It is the gateway from the East to the West, and vice versa. It is the centre of the trade route of South-east Asia connecting Australia and New Zealand. So, strategically speaking, we become a bone of contention in times of war, although we may not have any aggressive intentions of any kind. But we cannot deny, or under-estimate, or overlook the military value and importance of Singapore strategically. Although we are not going to invade anybody, we must not be weak-kneed. We must not be cowed.

    In addition to the military aspect, there is also the social aspect to be considered. Singapore has a population of about two million. If we want to stabilise the situation in Singapore, we must have a very closely-knit society before we can survive. The National Service (Amendment) Bill provides a certain significance in this respect in that attempts can be made to mobilise the people so as to bring about a closely-knit society. At the same time, we have

Column: 1201

to bear in mind that we have no resources other than manpower. The people in the age group of 18 or so are even more valuable in terms of manpower, and we must make full use of these resources and make all the people responds to the national service call. To this extent, I feel that if we can fully tap the youthful energies of our people and make use of the spring source of our nation, then it is in keeping with the aspirations of our people and we can create a very bright future.

    The next point I wish to go into is this. Although we call this national service, it must, of necessity, be connected with the nation, which, in the eyes of the Communists, cannot stand on its own, because the Communists themselves have no national consciousness. If they are to follow Marx, Engels or anybody of that kind, they will try to make use of class conflict or struggle by which they will try to suppress the people and make use of the class struggle as a weapon to suppress the people and to destroy the nation as their ultimate aim. They will start the rule of the proletariat instead. We must, of necessity, give vent to the spirit of democracy so as to protect our way of life. To do this, I personally feel that we must take the opportunity to review the policies of the Defence Ministry. For example, the inculcation of national consciousness is a very important job. I do not know whether it has already been accomplished. In the Officers' Mess of the People's Defence Force, we have not seen the reflection of society in the rank and file. Although it is said that the men and boys are supposed to have come from a multi-racial society, we are unable to see any Chinese newspaper or national language newspaper. Nor are our military songs sung in the Malay language or the national language. In the regular forces, we understand that they are using a kind of trumpet, instead of a bell, to inform the people of meal times. Up to date we do not have any military songs in the national language. So the People's Defence Force has not done its own part in bringing about a greater sense of national consciousness.

Column: 1202

If an explanation can be given, I shall be very happy to hear it.

    The next point is that we are Back-benchers in the ruling Party and we have some personal experience in military service and we have undergone a certain kind of training. The people from our ruling Party must set a good example by joining national service. This will nail the lies and the smears of the anti-national elements who say that we are hiding behind the people who are used as cannon fodder. So we must set a good example at the very beginning. We must put ourselves in uniform first. From the branches and headquarters of our Party, we must come forward in uniform to show the people that we are setting a good example. I do not know whether the Minister concerned has given some thought to this aspect so that he will not receive undue criticism. I hope some explanation will be forthcoming in this respect.

    Finally, Mr Speaker, Sir, when we call up the people for national service, we must not be very much concerned with the payment of allowances or other remunerations, otherwise it would appear that we are engaging employees to do a job.

    Sir, I support the Bill.

    Mr Ng Kah Ting (Punggol): Mr Speaker, Sir, I think national service is the necessary preparation through rigid discipline, military or otherwise, of the citizens for duty to the nation. This service in defence of the community undoubtedly can be termed a noble duty.

    Our Republic, though barely older than two years, has made great strides in the housing and industrial fields, and socially, too, has yet to mould a community of varied racial origins into one nation possessing the spirit of national consciousness. However, our assets are the youths and I think the Government has been wise to note this and exploit it to the country's full benefit. The slogan, "The youths of today are the leaders of tomorrow" is particularly true. Through the youths, we must cultivate national consciousness and other

Column: 1203

values of social responsibility which are essential and which we desire to instill in our entire community.

    According to the Bill, national service means service in the Army, People's Defence Force, the Special Constabulary and the Vigilante Corps. It also sets out the age groups to be called up and how long they are required to serve full-time as well as part- time.

    Amongst the number of important amendments to the National Service Ordinance, 1952, of Malaysia in its application to Singapore is one in which powers will be vested in the Minister who may "from time to time, by notice in the Gazette" call up youths for national service. Therefore, any proclamation for call-up would be done by the Minister instead of the President being required to proclaim it. I shall be glad if the Minister of Defence can explain why such a prerogative will now be vested in him.

    My next point is about the age groups to be called up. According to this Bill, 18 year-olds would be required to serve two years full-time and twelve years part-time. I am glad to note that jobs would be awaiting them upon their completion of the two-year full-time service. This is noteworthy in that it gives security to these youths who will not be unduly worried over employment when called upon to serve the country for two years full-time and ultimately twelve years part-time.

    However, I would be grateful if the Minister would kindly inform this House how many youths would the ten per cent constitute, and what expenditure would be expended on this matter. Furthermore, would it not be wiser if the Government, instead of calling up the 18 year-olds, extend the age group, say, from 18 to 25? I am suggesting this because, in this way, we would be able to equip our youths with the necessary training by which the development of spirit, bearing and skill would be more beneficial to the country as a whole and in which the spirit of national consciousness would be further instilled.

Column: 1204

And this would meet the requirement of a small and newly independent nation like Singapore - the preparedness that would ensure the survival and continued progress of the nation.

    Another point is that we know very well that a good number of these 18 year-olds have left secondary schools and many are pursuing higher education. In this respect, will the Minister concerned see to it that whilst they are undergoing national service, their educational pursuits will not be impeded? And for those in the higher institutions of learning, would it not be feasible to group these conscripts and place them under centralised training at a place closer to them whereby minimum time is spent on transport so that no cause for complaint would arise on the question of their studies being hampered or impeded because they have to spend much time in travelling to and from their place of training? This aspect of training, of course, refers to military training for which allowances are paid to cover transport charges and laundry charges for uniforms issued.

    However, as the Bill clearly states, persons "not being less than eighteen years of age" and who are liable to register under this Ordinance shall be liable to be called up for service in the Vigilante Corps. We all know the usefulness of the Vigilante Corps and the notable work they have done in the past 2« years. The Government, whilst realising the importance of the Vigilante Corps, has seen fit to include service in it as part and parcel of national service. I gather that the Vigilante Corps have been formed at community centre levels and that their duties are mainly to patrol the kampongs and along the shores. These members are doing an admirable job and we have come across occasions when Vigilante Corps members have helped to apprehend burglars and thieves, prevented illegal immigrants and performed a host of public-spirited duties. They are doing this purely on a voluntary basis and this displays a high spirit of social responsibility. It is also manifest that they are not paid any allowance when they go on

Column: 1205

duty except when the management committees of community centres have to foot the bill for coffee and titbits. It has been suggested that Vigilante Corps members be paid a token sum of money as enjoyed by volunteers in the Special Constabulary and the People's Defence Force. I support this suggestion and no doubt the Minister concerned may argue and say that the Vigilante Corps members enjoy a wider range of recreational facilities. But I must stress that the other forces have such facilities, too. Moreover, service in the Vigilante Corps would be national service, too, and I think it is only fair that those who would be required to serve in the Vigilante Corps be paid a nominal sum when they go on duty.

    Sir, coming back to the Bill in general, we all know that national service exists in almost all countries in the world. It is the fundamental responsibility of every citizen to answer the call of national service, if we do not take the necessary steps to protect ourselves from the enemies of our nation in order to be able to live in peace and security, I do not think anybody, or any country for that matter, can guarantee our freedom, unless we wish to be subjects of another country! I do not think this is what the people of Singapore want!

    Singapore, being a small independent country, stands on the southern tip of the Malay Peninsula and it is situated in a position of immense strategic importance. Therefore, it is only right and in the interests of the people and country that we must never allow ourselves to be caught unprepared, as what happened in the Second World War when the Japanese invaded Singapore. Hence the necessity of having a body of disciplined fighting force able to rotect life and property and most important of all - the survival of the country -the existence of this tiny island State in this corner of the turbulent world.

    It is a well-known fact that if a country shows verve, grit and determination to survive, she will not be molested. The stakes will be too high and the price too heavy to pay if we are a passive lot.

Column: 1206



    Moreover, the character of our community is such that Singapore is a rootless society. Her races are of varied migrant origins. Those who came to Singapore more than a century ago did not intend to make Singapore their home and country. But they have, over a period of more than a century, left behind well over two million people who today make up the population of the Republic of Singapore. The rootless and disorganised society of yesterday will thus have to be an organised society of today. This is unique in the history of Singapore.

    As I have said, we are now independent and I am sure that all will agree with me when I say that there is no place for us to go to if we are told off by a stronger neighbour. Hence the paramount importance of our Republic to organise a society in which there exists a sense of social responsibility and national consciousness.

    So national service will be implemented in the very near future. I do not think anybody today in Singapore will be against it. More than a decade ago, people did not understand the reasons for such service, and thus the Communists were able to exploit the issue, resulting in the call-up being a failure. Today the situation is entirely changed. For instance, young men and women have responded far beyond expectations by joining the People's Defence Force and the People's Defence Force (Women). I would therefore suggest to the Minister concerned to increase the intake to, say, 50 per cent instead of 10 per cent of the youths to be called up.

    Furthermore, if national service continues for ten years during which time an organised society will emerge, Singapore then will be a changed place where her citizens will not only live in confidence and pride but the Republic will also last as long as time.

    Therefore, in summing up, I would urge all youths who are liable to be called up to rise at once with one voice and respond to this call of duty to the nation.

Column: 1207



3.15 p.m.

    Mr S. Rajoo (Farrer Park): Mr Speaker, Sir, may I take this opportunity to say a few words on the National Service (Amendment) Bill which is now before the House for its Second Reading? This Bill provides for the conscription of potential manpower of our Island Republic which has been hitherto left untapped.
